===Tax avoidance===
===Tax avoidance===

Like a number of other major US corporations, Google is known to be using a tax avoidance strategies known as the [[Double Irish Arrangement|Double Irish]] and the [[Double Irish Arrangement#Dutch Sandwich|Dutch Sandwich]].<ref name="bloom">Chitum, Ryan (2007). "How 60 billion are lost in tax loopholes", Bloomberg</ref><ref name="bloom2010">{{Cite web
+
Like a number of other major US corporations, Google is known to be using two tax avoidance strategies known as the [[Double Irish Arrangement|Double Irish]] and the [[Double Irish Arrangement#Dutch Sandwich|Dutch Sandwich]].<ref name="bloom">Chitum, Ryan (2007). "How 60 billion are lost in tax loopholes", Bloomberg</ref><ref name="bloom2010">{{Cite web
|url= http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-21/google-2-4-rate-shows-how-60-billion-u-s-revenue-lost-to-tax-loopholes.html/
|url= http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-10-21/google-2-4-rate-shows-how-60-billion-u-s-revenue-lost-to-tax-loopholes.html/
|title=Google 2.4% Rate Shows How $60 Billion Lost to Tax Loopholes - Bloomberg
|title=Google 2.4% Rate Shows How $60 Billion Lost to Tax Loopholes - Bloomberg
|work=www.bloomberg.com
|work=www.bloomberg.com
|accessdate=2010-10-31
|accessdate=2010-10-31
â
}}</ref> These strategies use payments between related entities in a corporate structure to shift income from a higher-tax country of organization (e.g. the US or the UK for Google) to a lower-tax country (in this case Bermuda and Ireland). It relies on the fact that [[taxation in the Republic of Ireland|Irish tax law]] does not include [[transfer pricing]] regulations.<ref name="Darby">Joseph B. Darby III, "[http://www.gtlaw.com/portalresource/lookup/wosid/contentpilot-core-2301-5813/pdfCopy.pdf?view=attachment International Tax Planning: Double Irish More than Doubles the Tax Saving]", Practical US/International Tax Strategies 11(9), 15 May 2007</ref>
+
}}</ref> These strategies use payments between related entities in a corporate structure to shift income from a higher-tax country of organization (e.g. the US or the UK for Google) to a lower-tax country (in this case Bermuda and Ireland). The Double Irish relies on the fact that [[taxation in the Republic of Ireland|Irish tax law]] does not include [[transfer pricing]] regulations.<ref name="Darby">Joseph B. Darby III, "[http://www.gtlaw.com/portalresource/lookup/wosid/contentpilot-core-2301-5813/pdfCopy.pdf?view=attachment International Tax Planning: Double Irish More than Doubles the Tax Saving]", Practical US/International Tax Strategies 11(9), 15 May 2007</ref>
This practice cut Google's overseas tax rate to 2.4 percent, the lowest of the top five U.S. technology companies and reduced Google's tax payments by $3.1 billion from 2007 to 2009<ref name="bloom2010"/>. According to Abraham J. Briloff, a professor emeritus of accounting at Baruch College in New York who has examined Googleâs tax disclosures says that Google is "perpetrating evil under our noses".<ref name="bloom2010"/> However, Google received approval from the IRS in 2006 for its transfer pricing arrangement in a secret pact known as an advanced pricing agreement.<ref name="bloom2010"/>
This practice cut Google's overseas tax rate to 2.4 percent, the lowest of the top five U.S. technology companies and reduced Google's tax payments by $3.1 billion from 2007 to 2009<ref name="bloom2010"/>.
